facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 676 of 1965 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13,16, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 676 of 1965. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, Appel from the judgment and order dated September 13,16, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 2 of 1963.

facts.text: The respondent is a firm registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act during the assessment years 1958-59, 1959-60, and 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a firm which, for purposes of assessment under the Income-tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act , was registered under section 26A of the Act during the assessment years 1958-59, 1959-60, and 1960-61.

facts.text: The respondent earned income from property, ready business in kappas, and speculation business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was earning income from property, ready business in kappas, and also from speculation business carried on an extensive scale.

facts.text: During assessment year 1958-59, income from property was Rs. 1,369/- and from ready business Rs. 28,449/- with speculation loss of Rs. 6,26,606/-

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment year 1958-59, the income from property was assessed at Rs. 1,369/- and from ready business at Rs. 28,449/-. There was a loss of Rs. 6,26,606/- in the speculation business.

facts.text: In 1958-59, Income-tax Officer charged tax on total income from property and ready business Rs. 29,818/- without setting off speculation loss per first proviso to S. 24(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, in making the assessment for that year, charged tax on the total of the income from property and ready business which amounted to Rs. 29,818/-. The loss of Rs. 6,26,606/- was number set off against this profit in view of the provisions of the first proviso to S. 24 1  of the Act.

facts.text: In 1958-59, speculation loss of Rs. 6,26,606/- was apportioned between partners by Income-tax Officer under second proviso to S. 24(1).

anchor.surface_text: This loss was, however, apportioned between the partners by the Income-tax Officer, purporting to act under the second proviso to the said subsection.

facts.text: In 1959-60, there was income from property, loss in ready business and speculation business; net loss of Rs. 1,239/- from ready business reduced by property income was apportioned between partners.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in the next assessment year 1959-60, where there was income from property and loss in ready business as well as speculation business, numbertax was imposed, as the loss in ready business exceeded the income from property. The net loss of Rs. 1,239/- worked out on the basis of loss in ready business reduced by the income from property, was apportioned between the partners.

facts.text: In 1959-60, speculation loss of Rs. 5,416/- was apportioned between partners.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the speculation loss of Rs. 5,416/- was also apportioned between the partners on the same basis as was done in the preceding assessment year 1958-59.

facts.text: In 1960-61, income from property Rs. 1,014/-, loss from ready business Rs. 21,197/-, profit from speculation Rs. 6,19,784/-; net income computed taking all three.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1960-61, there was an income of Rs. 1,014/- from property, and a loss of Rs. 21,197/- from ready business. In addition, there was a profit of Rs. 6,19,784/- in the speculation business.

facts.text: In 1960-61, first proviso to s.24(1) did not apply due to profit in speculation business.

anchor.surface_text: Since this year there was a profit in speculation business, the first proviso to s. 24 1  did number apply, and the net income of the respondent was worked out by taking all the three figures into account.

facts.text: Respondent claimed set off of speculation losses from 1958-59 and 1959-60 against 1960-61 speculation profits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed that in the assessment of the respondents income in this year, the respondent was entitled to set off the speculation losses of the two preceding assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 against the profits earned from speculation business in this year,

facts.text: Respondent argued Income-tax Officer wrongly apportioned speculation losses in prior years under second proviso to s.24(1).

anchor.surface_text: urging that the Income-tax Officer in the two earlier years was wrong in apportioning the loss between the partners.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected respondent's plea for set off in 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was rejected by the Income-tax Officer whose order was up held by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted respondent's plea and held speculation losses from prior years adjustable against 1960-61 speculation profit.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, however, accepted the plea of the respondent and held that the speculation losses sustained by the respondent in the two preceding assessment years must be adjusted against the profit earned in the account year in question in speculation business.

facts.text: At request of Commissioner of Income-tax, Tribunal referred question of law to Gujarat High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, at the request of the Commissioner of Income-tax, the following question of law was referred by the Tribunal for opinion to the High Court of Gujarat

facts.text: Referred question: Whether Tribunal correct in holding speculation losses of 1958-59 and 1959-60 set off against 1960-61 speculation profit of Rs. 6,19,784/-

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case and on a true interpretation of the various provisions of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, the Tribunal was companyrect in holding that speculation losses of the Respondent firm  assessee firm  for the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 should be set off against its speculation profit of Rs. 6,19,784/- in its assessment for the assess- ment year 1960-61.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court upheld Tribunal's view and answered question in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the view of the Tribunal and answered the question in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax brought appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has number been brought up to this Court by the Commissioner of Income-tax on certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view on interpretation of second proviso to s.24(1).

anchor.surface_text: The language used in the second proviso, thus, itself leads to the companyclusion that the decision arrived at by the High Court was companyrect, even though on a different reasoning.

facts.text: In 1958-59 and 1959-60, Income-tax Officer did not set off speculation losses against income from property or ready business.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, in making the assessment for that year, charged tax on the total of the income from property and ready business which amounted to Rs. 29,818/-. The loss of Rs. 6,26,606/- was number set off against this profit in view of the provisions of the first proviso to S. 24 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld Income-tax Officer's order rejecting set off.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was rejected by the Income-tax Officer whose order was up held by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

arguments.claim: Purpose of s.24(1) and (2) must be considered in interpreting second proviso to s.24(1)

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question referred to the High Court obviously depends on the interpretation of the second proviso to s. 24 1 of the Act. In interpreting this provision, the purpose of s. 24 1 and 2 has to be kept in view.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was clearly right in the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 in not setting off the losses in the speculative business against the income earned in those years either from property or from ready business in kappas.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the Income-tax Officer was clearly right in the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 in not setting off the losses in the speculative business against the income earned in those years either from property or from ready business in kappas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First proviso to s.24(1) excludes speculation losses from set-off against non-speculation income when computing total income.

holdings.text: The second proviso to s.24(1) refers only to losses computed under the principal clause read with the first proviso, excluding speculation losses, and does not permit apportionment of speculation losses between partners of a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the expression any such loss in this part of the second proviso can only refer to the loss computed for purposes of applying the principal clause of s. 24(1) taken together with the first proviso. That will, therefore, be the loss suffered by the unregistered firm in businesses other than speculative business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreting 'any such loss' to include speculation losses would nullify the first proviso; harmonious construction excludes them.

holdings.text: The second part of the second proviso to s.24(1) also excludes speculation losses, which cannot be apportioned between partners of a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, in this part also, the words any loss must refer to the loss computed for purposes of the principal clause taken together with the first proviso, and will, therefore, not comprise in it the loss in speculative business which is not to be taken into account under the first proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Apportionment and set-off of apportioned losses would circumvent exclusion under first proviso.

holdings.text: The language of the second proviso leads to the conclusion that the High Court was correct in holding that speculation losses of prior years should be set off against speculation profits in 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: The language used in the second proviso, thus, itself leads to the conclusion that the decision arrived at by the High Court was correct, even though on a different reasoning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation confirms no apportionment of speculation losses, allowing firm carry forward.

holdings.text: The first proviso to s.23(5)(a) does not apply to losses in speculative business of a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this proviso refers to the loss incurred by a registered firm in speculative business which is not to be taken into account when computing the total income of the registered firm under s. 23(1), (3) and (4) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.23(5)(a) applies only to total income computed under s.23(1),(3),(4); speculation losses excluded therefrom by s.24(1) first proviso.

holdings.text: Proviso (c) to s.24(2) permits a registered firm to carry forward and set off unapportioned losses, which are speculation losses not taken into account in total income computation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso contemplates unapportioned losses for firms, aligning with exclusion of speculation losses from apportionment under s.24(1) second proviso.
